clinical_study.brief_title: The Psychosocial Effects of Systemic / Family Constellation
clinical_study.official_title: The Psychosocial Effects of Systemic / Family Constellation: An Observational Follow-up Study

lead_sponsor.agency: Károli Gáspár University of the Reformed Church in Hungary

clinical_study.source: Károli Gáspár University of the Reformed Church in Hungary

brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to investigate the psychosocial effects of systemic / family constellation. The method of systemic / family constellation refers to an approach which integrates ideas from family systems therapy with elements from psychodrama. The constellations are conducted in a group based seminar-setting, each seminar lasting two days.
Considering the very limited amount of empirical data on this method, the study design is a simple pre-post one with a 6-months follow-up. The study will be observational: the researchers will not manipulate who receives the intervention; instead they invite all clients (individuals from the general population) attending these therapeutic workshops run independently of the research process. Given the limited amount of evidence on this therapeutic method, special attention will be given to monitor potential adverse outcomes to establish intervention safety.
It is hypothesized that participation in a family constellation seminar might decrease potential psychological symptoms and will not result in adverse outcomes.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in scores on the Brief Symptom Inventory
primary_outcome.time_frame: Before, 1 month after and 6 months after the intervention
primary_outcome.description: A broad spectrum of psychopathological symptoms including somatization, obsession-compulsion, interpersonal sensitivity, depression, anxiety, hostility, phobic anxiety, paranoid ideation, and psychoticism

primary_outcome.measure: Change in answers to ad hoc items developed for qualitative analysis
primary_outcome.description: These items are developed by the study authors to 1) screen for any potential adverse outcomes as a result of the intervention, 2) better understand the treatment goals of individuals participating in this form of therapy and how these relate to what they perceive as the outcome of the intervention

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in scores on the Experience in Personal Social Systems Questionnaire
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Before, 1 month after and 6 months after the intervention
secondary_outcome.description: Assessment of how the members of a personal social system experience their situation within that system.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in scores on the Patient Health Questionnaire Somatic Symptom Severity Scale (PHQ-15)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Before, 1 month after and 6 months after the intervention
secondary_outcome.description: The PHQ-15 includes 15 somatic symptoms (headache, stomach pain, chest pain, dizziness, etc.) that account for more than 90% of symptoms seen in primary care (exclusive of upper respiratory symptoms)

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in scores on the SCOFF
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Before, 1 month after and 6 months after the intervention
secondary_outcome.description: The SCOFF is a brief screener to detect increased risk for eating disorders

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in scores on ad hoc items to assess behavioral and substance-related addictions
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Before, 1 month after and 6 months after the intervention
secondary_outcome.description: Items assess perceived problem severity with addictions

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in scores on the Meaning in Life Questionnaire (MLQ)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Before, 1 month after and 6 months after the intervention
secondary_outcome.description: The MLQ assesses the perceived level of the presence and search for meaning in an individual's life

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in scores on the World Health Organization Wellbeing Index (WBI-5)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Before, 1 month after and 6 months after the intervention
secondary_outcome.description: The WBI-5 captures the general well-being of the individuals

arm_group.description: Participants of systemic / family constellation workshops

intervention.description: Systemic / family constellation integrates elements from psychodrama, family sculpture, and spontaneous dramatizations of intra- and interpersonal processes, while spatially visualizing family dynamics. Family constellations stimulate change through the following ways: 1) making visible the spatial arrangement of relationships within a conflictual system; 2) providing access to the insights of unrelated third parties regarding the sensations, feelings, and thoughts they experienced while representing family members within the constellation; and 3) making observable (from the outside) and experienceable (from within) the transformation of the problem constellation into the solution constellation [Hunger, Weinhold, Bornhäuser, Link, & Schweitzer, 2015].

study_pop.textblock: Individuals from the general population who seek help through family constellation seminars for various mild to moderate psychological symptoms.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Self-referred and registered for a family constellation workshop with one of the two therapists (a clinical psychologist and a psychiatrist) who were willing to collaborate with the researchers of the present study
Exclusion Criteria:
- Age under 18 years
- Currently suffers from a diagnosed mental disorder
- Participated actively (not merely as a "representative") in a family constellation intervention in the 12 months preceding baseline assessment

patient_data.ipd_description: The investigators have not requested permission from their study participants to make their data available to others to increase participants' sense of confidentiality and so willingness to participate in the study. As a consequence, in case of a data sharing request, the investigators would have to seek for additional explicit permission from the participants. As the investigators have committed to destroy participant contact data after finishing the study, the chances of such data sharing seem slim. However, the investigators are more than happy to conduct alternative analyses based on interested colleagues' suggestions / inquiry and share the raw output (including analytic syntax) of such analyses with those making the inquiry.
